article_title: The Byzantine Reconquest of North Africa

paragraphs.text: The Byzantine reconquest of North Africa, a significant military campaign in the 6th century, was undertaken by Emperor Justinian I . This event occurred within a broader historical context of shifting power dynamics in the Mediterranean, following the decline of the Western Roman Empire and the rise of new powers, including the Vandal kingdom in North Africa . The Vandals, after crossing the Gibraltar Strait in 429 CE and capturing Carthage in 439 CE, controlled the region for approximately a century . The Byzantine Empire, seeking to restore Roman imperial authority, viewed the Vandal kingdom as an illegitimate power and a threat to its interests .

Several factors motivated Justinian's decision to launch the reconquest. One of the main reasons was religious, aiming to liberate the African Catholic population from Arian Vandal persecution . The African Catholic clergy enthusiastically welcomed the Byzantine conquest, as evidenced in a letter to Pope John II in May 535 . Justinian also sought to re-establish Roman control over vital economic resources in North Africa, including its agricultural lands and trade networks . The reconquest was seen as a political liberation of Roman people from barbarian oppressors .

The Byzantine military campaign was initiated in 533 CE under the leadership of General Belisarius . The expeditionary force, though including Arian soldiers, mainly barbarians, was largely composed of Byzantine troops . Belisarius's amphibious assault proved successful, leading to decisive victories against the Vandals at Ad Decimum on September 13, 533, and Tricamarum in 534 CE . King Gelimer, who reigned from June 15, 530, to September 15, 533, was captured and sent to Byzantium . The Vandal kingdom was dismantled, and North Africa was brought back under Byzantine control . The celebration of St. Cyprian's Day in Carthage on September 14, 533, occurred after the Arian priests fled following Gelimer's defeat at Ad Decimum .

Despite the initial success, the Byzantine reconquest faced numerous challenges. Belisarius's initial distrust of the African population was evident in security measures following the landing in 533 . A major revolt of Arian troops occurred in the spring of 536, taking the authorities by surprise . This revolt was partly caused by Justinian's anti-Arian policies and the actions of Vandal Arian clergymen who incited the soldiers . Vandal women also played a significant role in the 536 revolt, urging their husbands to reclaim land and opposing the suppression of Arianism . Subsequent rebellions, led by Stotzas (536-546) and Guntharic (546), continued to involve Arian soldiers and Vandals . The Laguatan, a Berber tribal confederation, also posed a significant challenge to Byzantine authority . In 523 AD, a Vandal army was defeated in Tripolitania by the Laguatan under Cabaon . In 543 AD, 79 Laguatan chiefs were killed at a meeting with Dux Sergius at Lepcis, leading to a major revolt lasting until 548 AD .

Following the reconquest, the Byzantine Empire implemented administrative and societal changes in North Africa. The administration primarily consisted of individuals from the Eastern Roman Empire, leading to the "Byzantinization of African society" . The Codex Justinianus mentions the Tripolitanian province's military commander temporarily residing at Lepcis Magna . The African Catholic clergy played a significant role in resisting Byzantine imperial attempts to subvert Chalcedonian orthodoxy . The African Church resisted imperial interference during the "three chapters" controversy under Emperor Justinian . The Byzantine presence also led to a revival of trans-Saharan trade, which had ended with the fall of Roman rule . Christianity spread to the Fezzan following the Byzantine reconquest .

The Byzantine Empire invested in the construction and maintenance of fortifications in North Africa to secure its control. A Byzantine wall circuit was constructed at Lepcis Magna, utilizing re-purposed Roman materials . The Codex Justinianus mentions the Tripolitanian province's military commander temporarily residing at Lepcis Magna . The thesis by R. Pringle examines documentary and archaeological evidence for sixth-century fortifications in Byzantine Africa . The article discusses excavations conducted in the Severan Basilica at Lepcis Magna during the summer of 1951 to examine the unexcavated Byzantine levels .

sections.subtitle: The Plague of Justinian and its Impact

paragraphs.text: Justinian's Plague, which began in 541 CE, had a devastating impact on the Byzantine Empire, including its North African territories . The plague's high mortality rate caused a severe labor shortage, impacting both the economy and military . The plague also impacted campaigns in Africa, where revolts and manpower shortages hampered military efforts .

Despite Justinian's efforts, the Byzantine presence in North Africa was ultimately unsustainable. The lands gained in North Africa by Belisarius were lost a few years after Justinian's death in 565 CE . Between 632 and 670 CE, Muslim Arabs conquered Near Eastern and North African lands previously under Byzantine control . The armies of Mohammad conquered Byzantine provinces in Asia and Africa during the early 7th century . Antioch was lost to the Arabs in 637 CE . The Arab invasion of Egypt began in 639 CE . The fall of Alexandria in 642 CE ended Byzantine rule in Egypt . Constans II's attempts to secure Italy and North Africa were part of a strategy to regain the initiative from the Arabs . The Arab conquest marks the end of the period covered in the excerpt .

The Byzantine reconquest of North Africa, though ultimately short-lived, had a lasting impact on the region. It marked a period of renewed Roman influence, religious revival, and economic activity . The Byzantine presence also contributed to the cultural and artistic landscape of North Africa, as evidenced by the blend of Roman, Constantinopolitan, and Syrian influences in Byzantine religious art . The reconquest also set the stage for the subsequent Arab conquest, which would fundamentally reshape the region's history and culture .
